FLUTO'S FIRESIDE,
WITH A

PEEP

AT THE CHAMPS ELYSEES,

BUT NOT A Li MODE DE PARIS.

" Hark! be strikes hia golden lyre;
See the shady forms advance ;
Thy stone, O Sisyphus, stands still;
Ixion rests upon his wheel,
And the pale spectres dance.
H e sung and * * * * consented
To hear the poets prayer—
Siera Proserpine relenle i.
And gave him back the fair."—POPE.

DADJIIERE D'ENF EJt,
EQUALLY Ui\PARISIAN.
" But soon, too soon, the lover turns his eyes—
Again she falls, again she dies."—POPE.

A BACCHANALIAN PROCESSION.

Rolling in meanders,

H e makes his moan,
And calls her ghost
For ever, ever lost!"—POPE-

PLUTO'S FIRESIDE,
WITH A »

PEEP AT THE CHAMPS ELI SEES, BUT NOT A LA MODE DE PARIS.
"• Hark! lie strikes his golden lyre;
See I lie shady forms advance;
Thy stone, O Sisyphus, stands Mill;
Ixion rests upon his wheel,
And the pale spectres dance.
H e sung and * * * * contented
To hear the poet's prayer—
Stern Proserpine relented,
And gave him back the fair."—POPE.

Again she falls, again she dies."—POPE.

SWIMMING of the HEAD down ihe HEBRUS!
( A Classical
Complaint.)

most flattering approbation:—Her Third Appearance will be on Friday next, in the N E W MUSICAL DRAMA.

received with the warmest applause, and will make her Second Appearance in a few dins.

E N G L I S H OPERA

COMPANY,

Royal Olympic T h e a t r e ,
NEWCASTLE STREET, STRAND.

It is respectfully announced that

M a s t e r s S A N E S T and EDWARD

Aged 8 and l O T e a r s only,
have arrived from Germany, with the subjoined
recommendation for extraordinary Talents, from the
celebrated Composer, L O U I S S P O H R . T h e y made
their F i r s t Appearance on Wednesday, the 11th inst.
at the Benefit Concert of Madame S H R O D E R D E V R I E N T
where they were received with acclamations of
applause; and will perform, together, at this T h e a t r e ,

OUT SATURDAY NEXT,
A Concert'ante forTwo
Violins,
And a DIVERTIMENTO.
T h e P r o p r i e t o r has no hesitation in pledging- himself
as to the peculiar merits of these Young* Gentlemen,
who have already received the unqualified approbation
of most of the principal Musicians and Amateurs of
this Country.

Translation of a Testimonial from Louis Spohr.
" / , the undersigned, consider it my duty to draw the attention 0/ the lovers 0/ Music, to
the wonderful Musical Talent of these Young Children (the Masters EICHHORN.J
However
much my expectations had been raised by the favourable reports of the Publick Journals, on the
performances of these Young Artists, they were greatly surpassed by the great security, precision,
and purity of tone, with which these Boys treat the most difficult of all instruments, (the Violin) :
and I willingly own, that I did not hitherto think it possible, the talent for Music could attain #0
high a cultivation in so tender an age.
"LOU/S
SPOHfi"
Cassel,
April 24th, 1832.
9. G. Fairbroth.r, I*rint.r, Kx.t.r Court, Strand,

(

E N G L I S H OPERA

COMPANY,

Royal Olympic T h e a t r e ,
NEWCASTLE STREET. STRAND.

I t is respectfully announced that

M a s t e r s E R N E S T and EDWARD

EICHHORN,
Aged 8 and l O T e a r s only,
have arrived from Germany, with the subjoined
recommendation for extraordinary Talents, from the
celebrated Composer, L O U I S S P O H R . T h e y made
their F i r s t Appearance on Wednesday, the U t h inst.
at the Benefit Concert of Madame S H R O D E R D E \ RIEMT
where they were received with acclamations of
applause; and will perform, together, at this T h e a t r e .

OUT SATURDAY ItfEXT,
A Concertante for Two Violins,
And a DIVERTIMENTO.
T h e P r o p r i e t o r has no hesitation in pledging himself
as to the peculiar merits of these Y o u n g Gentlemen,
who have already received the unqualified approbation
of most of the principal Musicians and A in at euro of
this Country.

Translation of a Testimonial from Louis Spohr.
" / , the undersigned, consider it my duty to draw the attention of the lovers of Music, f#
the wonderful Musical Talent of these Young Children (the Masters EICHHORN.)
However
much my expectations had been raised by the favourable reports of the Publick Journals, on the
' performances of these Young Artists, they were greatly surpassed by the great security, precision,
and purity of tone, with which these Boys treat the most difficult of all instruments, (the Violin);
and I willingly own, that I did not hitherto think it possible, the talent for Music could attain *O
high a cultivation in so tender an age.
"LOUTS SPOHR"
Cassel,

April 24th, 1632.
-T—«

•"

«

-—*

——

S. G. Fairbrother, Printer, Exeter Court, Itraud.

E N G L I S H OFERA COMPANY,

Royal Olympic Theatre,
NEWCASTLE STREET, STRAND.

It is respectfully announced that

M a s t e r s E R N E S T and EDWARD
Aged 8 and l O Y e a r s only,
have arrived from Germany, with the subjoined
recommendation for extraordinary Talents, from the
celebrated Composer, L O U I S S P O H R . T h e y made
their F i r s t Appearance on Wednesday, the 11th inst.
at the Benefit Concert of Madame S H R O D E R D E V R I E N T
where they were received with acclamations of
applause; and will perform, together, at this T h e a t r e ,

OUT S A T U R D A Y RTBXT,

A Concertante

for 1rieo

Violins,

And a DIVERTIMENTO.
T h e Proprietor has no hesitation in pledging himself
as to the peculiar merits of these Young Gentlemen,
who have already received the unqualified approbation
of most of the principal Musicians and Amateurs of
this Country.

Translation of a Testimonial from Louis Spohr.
" / , the undersigned, consider it my duty to draw the attention of the lovers of Music, U>
the wonderful Musical Talent of these Young Children (the Masters EICHHORN.)
However
much my expectations had been raised by the favourable reports of the Publick Journals, on the
performances of these Young Artists, they were greatly surpassed by the great security, precision,
and purity of tone, with which these Boys treat the most difficult of all instruments, (the Violin) ;
and I willingly own, that J did not hitherto think it possible, the talent for Music could attain so
high a cultivation in so tender an age.
u
LOUIS
SPQ0R."
Cassel,
April 24th, 1832.
S. G. Fawbrojkv.*, PriaWr, E s . t u Covtt, Straw*.

Translation of a Testimonial from Louis Spohr.
" / , the undersigned) consider it my duty to draw the attention of the lovers of Musict $9
the wonderful Musical Talent of these Young Children (the Masters EICHHORN.)
However
much my expectations had been raised by the favourable reports of the Publick Journals, on the
performances of these Young Artists, they were greatly surpassed by the great security, precision,
and purity of tone, with which these Boys treat the most difficult of all instruments, (the Violin) ;
and I willingly own, that I did not hitherto think it possible, the talent for Music could attain *o
high a cultivation in so tender an age.
"LOUIS
SPOHR"

April 24th, 1832.

12ICHHOBK,
Aged EIGHT and T E N Years, only,

h a v e a r r i v e d f r o m G e r m a n y , w i t h t h e s u b j o i n e d r e c o m m e n d a t i o n for e x t r a o r d i n a r y

at this Theatre, T H I S EVENING,

A C O N C E R T A N T E for T W O V I O L I N S ,

T R A N S L A T I O N O F A T E S T I M O N I A L F R O M LOUIS S P O H R .

" / , the undersigned, consider it my duty to draw the attention of the lovers of Music, to
the wonderful Musical Talent of these Young Children (the Masters EICHHORN.)
However
much my expectations had been raised by the favourable reports of the Publick Journals, on the
performances of these Young Artists, they were greatly surpassed by the great security, precision,
and purity of tone, with which these Boys treat the most difficult of all instruments, (the Violin) ;
and I willingly own, that I did not hitherto think it possible, the talent for Music could attain so
high a cultivation in so tender an age.
Cassel, April 24th, 1832.
"LOUIS
SPOHR."

PLUTO'S FIRESIDE,
oW"

WITH A

PEEP AT THE CHAMPS ELFSEHS,

BUT NOT A LA MODE J)E PARIS.

" Hark ! he strikes his golden lyre ;
See the shady forms advance ;
Thy stone, O Sisyphus, stands stilt;
Ixion rests upon his wheel,
And the pale spectres dance.
He sung and * * * * consented
To hear the poet's prayer—
Slern Proserpine relented.
And gave him back the fair.*'—I'OPE.

(A Classical Complaint).
" Yet even in death Eurydice he sung,

Eundicelhe floods;
Eurvdice the rocks, and hollow mountains rung."—POPE.

programme of the Scenery.

THE P A P U I A N B O W E R !
A BEAUTY-FULL, GRACE-FULL, and A-MUSE-ING SCENE,
'n the course of which will be realized, in accordance with the present taste for Tableaux,
Several design* from the Antique, including One o n Adonis—Ay Venn*.

A Fresco Groupe of the Muses, Graces, Love and Hymen.
" Even as the Sun with purple-coloured face,
Had la'en his last leave ot'die weeping morn ;
Uose-cheeked Adonis hied him to the chase,
Hunting he loved, but love lis laughed to scorn."—SHAKSPKARE.

DISTANT VIEW OF THE

CITY At PORT of P A P H O S !
AN KNCHANTI.\G SCENE.

" Tempus F u g i t . " — A L O G A T K CLOCK.
'• O day and night, but this is wondrous strange " — S H A K S P B A R E .
An incantation a la (Piy's) Fry—schufz !!! With a bow wow Chorus by the Dogs of War.

VIEW IN THE

I S L A N D OP CYPRUS!
A ROMANTIC SCENE;
Adonis killed by an A-Aoar-iginal inhabitant.
" So in our Woods the hunted Boar
On his native strength relics;
The Forest echoes with his roar,
In turn the hunter flies.''—T. D I B D I N .

An ASTRONOMICAL

SCJEJ¥JSI

Rising of a b r s n - I e w Moon, and Revolution of t h e p r i n c i p a l P l a n e t s In this H e m i s p h e r e ,
on a Novel S t a r r i n g System.

Visible only In the Olympic TPIreatee.

VBE P A P H I A N BOWER!
A BEAUTY-FULL, GRACE-FULL, and A-MUSE-ING SCENE,
I»» the course of which will be realized, in accordance with the present taste for Tableaux.
Several designs from the Antique, including one on Adonis—by

Venus.

THE P A P K I A N BOWER!
I

THE

Corent-Garden
COMPANY,
in offering their GRATEFUL ACKNOWLEDGMENTS to

A British

Public,

tor their Generous Support, and the consequent Success which has. thus
far, attended their Efforts, cannot refrain from expressing to that Public,
the astonishment with which they contemplate an announcement of the
He-Opening of the Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden, this Evening, (Monday),
with a FOREIGN O P E R A T I C COMPANY, aided by a portion of th«
Members of the T H E A T R E ROYAL, D R U R Y - L A N E ; after the Less**
had officially declared to the Company, that Covent-GarJen Theatre was
dosed for T H E SEASON.
Notwithstanding the P A I N F U L and U N P R E C E D E N T E D prodm*meat in which the

Corent- Garden

Company

?<L*is find themselves placed, They respectfully beg leave to announce to
their liberal Patrons, that their Exertions will be continued with increased
Vigour to merit their protecting Patronage, during the period to which
their License (granted to them by the Right Hon. the Lord Chamberlain,
in consideraion of the peculiar circumstances of their case) extends, v u . —
—The completion of the number of acting nights of the usual Cdvent-Garden, Season.

fYittcd by W. »ETPK>I DS. 9, Esetci^trewt, Strap*

THE

Covent-Garden
COXIEPANY,
In offering: their GRATEFUL ACKNOWLEDGMENTS to

A British

Public.,

for their Generous Support, and the consequent .Success which has, thus
far, attended their Efforts, cannot refrain from expressing to that Public,
the astonishment with which they contemplate an announcement of the
Re-Opening of the Theatre Royal, Covent-Garden, this Evening, (Monday),
with a FOREIGN OPERATIC COMPANY, aided by a portion of the
Members of the THEATRE ROYAL, DRURY-LANE; after the Less««
had officially declared to the Company, that Covent-Gardett Theatre was
Closed for THE SEASON.
Notwithstanding ihe PAINFUL and UNPRECEDENTED predWamtnt in which the

Covent- Garden

Company

rtKus find themselves placed, They respectfully >>eg leave to announce to
their liberal Patrons, that their Exertions will be continued with increased
Vigour to merit their protecting Patronage, during the period to which
their License (granted to them by the Right Hon. the Lord Chamberlain,
in consideraion of the peculiar circumstances of their case) extend*, viz.—
—The completion of the number of acting nights of the usual Cdyent-Carden Season.
PnnteU by W, REYNOLDS. 9, E-ctcr..trr.t, Strang

received a License to continue their Performance 0 until the usual number of nights shall have bean
completed, at the

T H E A T R E ROYAL, OLYMPIC,

most respectfully beg leave to announce to the Public, that the Lessee having
suddenly terminated his Season at an unprecedentedly early period, they have,
upon an application unanimously made, received a License to continue their
Performances until the usual number ot" nights shall have b*en completed, at the

Theatre

lloyal,

Olympic,

which will accordingly remain open, on their own

llesponmbUitit.

FRENCH FLAYS

MADAIHffi V K S T l t l S *
ROYAL OLYMPIC THEATRE.

The Nobility, Subscribers to the French Plays, and the Public,
are respectfully informed that this elegant Theatre will be
opened, with a New Company, for the Season, on
F R I D A Y , A P R I L 4th, 1834.
The Performances will commence at half-past Seven o Clock, with

CHACUN DE SON COTE.

ComMie Melte de Chant.
U. de ValmoRt, M. CLoup, Eugdne, son neveu, M . B R E S S A N , * • Tk. de Palait Royale.
Mademoiselle Gernance, M a d a m e I i I V I O N , " « 1'hiS.lrt de Cuon,
Camille, «a Nidee, M a d e m o i s e l l e E U G E N I E ,
duTHMtrede,
VarUtts.
After which, KIHST TIME,

L A S T N I G H T b u t O N E o f 31. L A F Q N D .
O^f In consequence of the indisposition of Mademoiselle
IRMA, the Piece of LEONTINE is unavoidably postponed
till Wednesday Evening. Many Families of Distinction having
made applications for a repetition of the favorite Piece of
JEAN, it will be performed with LA CHANOINESSE, which
was received last Friday with the most distinguished success,

Second Appearance of M. P E R L E T .
F R I D A Y , MAY 23rd, 1834.
By Desire of several Families of Distinction, who, on account of the
Performance at thr Opera House, were unable to attend the second representation of the favorite Piece of P H I L I P P E > which was received with
unbounded applause, and excited the deepest interest, it will be repeated for
the Last Time This Evening, in consequence of many Novelties being in pre"
paration, in which M. PERLET will appear.

Numerous applications having been made for a second representation of
Moliere's celebrated Comedy o/L AVARE, in which M.PERLETW* received
in the character of L'Avaie.wt/A most enthusiastic approbation, by an elegant
and overflowing Audience, that piece will be repeated, positively for the Last
Time, on Wednesday, with LA MAISON EN LOTERIE; ou, Le Malin
BOBIU.—Le Malin Bossu, by M. PERLfc.T. An early application for Boxes
it requested, as it will be impossible otherwise to retain them, on account of
the unprecedented demands.

EVERY EVENING.
The Performances are so arranged as to terminate as near Eleven as possible.
for the Boxes must be paid for when taken, and will be kept till the Half-Price.

No Money returned.

THE SUCCESSFUL N E W BURLETTA OF

T H E R E T O R T 4 Ol ICWKOUS,
is unavoidably postponed, in consequence of the continued indisposition of

Madame VESTRIS,
but it is confidently hoped that she will be sufficently recovered to appear To-morrow Evening.
The Performances are arranged to terminate as near Eleven as possible.
Places for the Boxes must he paid for when taken, and will be kept till the Half-Price.
